author: Harry Yorke
title: How to get 18 days off at Easter using just nine days annual leave: quirk of calander means workers can enjoy extra-long holiday
text:
23 February 2017 • 6:45pm 
A prolonged summer holiday may seem like a distant dream at this stage of the year. 
But thanks to the unusually early date on which Easter Sunday falls this year, employees looking to book an early getaway can enjoy 18 days holiday at the cost of just nine. 
With Easter falling on April 16, those looking to book time off work will be able to begin their holiday on Good Friday until the May bank holiday, ensuring that they capitalise on three bank holidays within a nine-day working calendar. 
It means that the standard employee entitled to a statutory 21 days paid leave can leave work on Thursday 13 April and return on the 2 May, having used less than half of their holiday quota. 
T he unexpected perk is due to the early arrival of the first full moon following the vernal equinox, used by Western churches to calculate the day on which Easter Sunday must fall. 
Traditionally, Easter was held the first Sunday after the Jewish festival of Passover. 
However, following the ruling of the Council of Nicaea in 325AD, Easter Sunday has since been determined by the arrival of the paschal full moon - meaning it must fall fall between March 22 and April 25. Mapped: The countries with the most public holidays 
T he welcome bonus is the second to have been gifted to Brits this year, after the Yuletide period saw Christmas Day and New Years Day fall on a Sunday. 
It meant that those employees normally required to book the festive period off work were able to save the days for later in the year. 
After this year’s festivities, those hoping to enjoy the same length of time off work will have to wait until 2019, when Good Friday falls on 19 April. Follow Telegraph News
